      17                 :            : // File: string_view.h
      18                 :            : // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
      19                 :            : //
      20                 :            : // This file contains the definition of the `absl::string_view` class. A
      21                 :            : // `string_view` points to a contiguous span of characters, often part or all of
      22                 :            : // another `std::string`, double-quoted std::string literal, character array, or even
      23                 :            : // another `string_view`.
      24                 :            : //
      25                 :            : // This `absl::string_view` abstraction is designed to be a drop-in
      26                 :            : // replacement for the C++17 `std::string_view` abstraction.
      27                 :            : #ifndef ABSL_STRINGS_STRING_VIEW_H_
      28                 :            : #define ABSL_STRINGS_STRING_VIEW_H_
      29                 :            : 
      30                 :            : #include <algorithm>
      31                 :            : #include "absl/base/config.h"
      32                 :            : 
      33                 :            : #ifdef ABSL_HAVE_STD_STRING_VIEW
      34                 :            : 
      35                 :            : #include <string_view>
      36                 :            : 
      37                 :            : namespace absl {
      38                 :            : using std::string_view;
      39                 :            : }  // namespace absl
      40                 :            : 
      41                 :            : #else  // ABSL_HAVE_STD_STRING_VIEW
      42                 :            : 
      43                 :            : #include <cassert>
      44                 :            : #include <cstddef>
      45                 :            : #include <cstring>
      46                 :            : #include <iosfwd>
      47                 :            : #include <iterator>
      48                 :            : #include <limits>
      49                 :            : #include <string>
      50                 :            : 
      51                 :            : #include "absl/base/internal/throw_delegate.h"
      52                 :            : #include "absl/base/macros.h"
      53                 :            : #include "absl/base/port.h"
      54                 :            : 
      55                 :            : namespace absl {
      56                 :            : 
      57                 :            : // absl::string_view
      58                 :            : //
      59                 :            : // A `string_view` provides a lightweight view into the std::string data provided by
      60                 :            : // a `std::string`, double-quoted std::string literal, character array, or even
      61                 :            : // another `string_view`. A `string_view` does *not* own the std::string to which it
      62                 :            : // points, and that data cannot be modified through the view.
      63                 :            : //
      64                 :            : // You can use `string_view` as a function or method parameter anywhere a
      65                 :            : // parameter can receive a double-quoted std::string literal, `const char*`,
      66                 :            : // `std::string`, or another `absl::string_view` argument with no need to copy
      67                 :            : // the std::string data. Systematic use of `string_view` within function arguments
      68                 :            : // reduces data copies and `strlen()` calls.
      69                 :            : //
      70                 :            : // Because of its small size, prefer passing `string_view` by value:
      71                 :            : //
      72                 :            : //   void MyFunction(absl::string_view arg);
      73                 :            : //
      74                 :            : // If circumstances require, you may also pass one by const reference:
      75                 :            : //
      76                 :            : //   void MyFunction(const absl::string_view& arg);  // not preferred
      77                 :            : //
      78                 :            : // Passing by value generates slightly smaller code for many architectures.
      79                 :            : //
      80                 :            : // In either case, the source data of the `string_view` must outlive the
      81                 :            : // `string_view` itself.
      82                 :            : //
      83                 :            : // A `string_view` is also suitable for local variables if you know that the
      84                 :            : // lifetime of the underlying object is longer than the lifetime of your
      85                 :            : // `string_view` variable. However, beware of binding a `string_view` to a
      86                 :            : // temporary value:
      87                 :            : //
      88                 :            : //   // BAD use of string_view: lifetime problem
      89                 :            : //   absl::string_view sv = obj.ReturnAString();
      90                 :            : //
      91                 :            : //   // GOOD use of string_view: str outlives sv
      92                 :            : //   std::string str = obj.ReturnAString();
      93                 :            : //   absl::string_view sv = str;
      94                 :            : //
      95                 :            : // Due to lifetime issues, a `string_view` is sometimes a poor choice for a
      96                 :            : // return value and usually a poor choice for a data member. If you do use a
      97                 :            : // `string_view` this way, it is your responsibility to ensure that the object
      98                 :            : // pointed to by the `string_view` outlives the `string_view`.
      99                 :            : //
     100                 :            : // A `string_view` may represent a whole std::string or just part of a std::string. For
     101                 :            : // example, when splitting a std::string, `std::vector<absl::string_view>` is a
     102                 :            : // natural data type for the output.
     103                 :            : //
     104                 :            : //
     105                 :            : // When constructed from a source which is nul-terminated, the `string_view`
     106                 :            : // itself will not include the nul-terminator unless a specific size (including
     107                 :            : // the nul) is passed to the constructor. As a result, common idioms that work
     108                 :            : // on nul-terminated strings do not work on `string_view` objects. If you write
     109                 :            : // code that scans a `string_view`, you must check its length rather than test
     110                 :            : // for nul, for example. Note, however, that nuls may still be embedded within
     111                 :            : // a `string_view` explicitly.
     112                 :            : //
     113                 :            : // You may create a null `string_view` in two ways:
     114                 :            : //
     115                 :            : //   absl::string_view sv();
     116                 :            : //   absl::string_view sv(nullptr, 0);
     117                 :            : //
     118                 :            : // For the above, `sv.data() == nullptr`, `sv.length() == 0`, and
     119                 :            : // `sv.empty() == true`. Also, if you create a `string_view` with a non-null
     120                 :            : // pointer then `sv.data() != nullptr`. Thus, you can use `string_view()` to
     121                 :            : // signal an undefined value that is different from other `string_view` values
     122                 :            : // in a similar fashion to how `const char* p1 = nullptr;` is different from
     123                 :            : // `const char* p2 = "";`. However, in practice, it is not recommended to rely
     124                 :            : // on this behavior.
     125                 :            : //
     126                 :            : // Be careful not to confuse a null `string_view` with an empty one. A null
     127                 :            : // `string_view` is an empty `string_view`, but some empty `string_view`s are
     128                 :            : // not null. Prefer checking for emptiness over checking for null.
     129                 :            : //
     130                 :            : // There are many ways to create an empty string_view:
     131                 :            : //
     132                 :            : //   const char* nullcp = nullptr;
     133                 :            : //   // string_view.size() will return 0 in all cases.
     134                 :            : //   absl::string_view();
     135                 :            : //   absl::string_view(nullcp, 0);
     136                 :            : //   absl::string_view("");
     137                 :            : //   absl::string_view("", 0);
     138                 :            : //   absl::string_view("abcdef", 0);
     139                 :            : //   absl::string_view("abcdef" + 6, 0);
     140                 :            : //
     141                 :            : // All empty `string_view` objects whether null or not, are equal:
     142                 :            : //
     143                 :            : //   absl::string_view() == absl::string_view("", 0)
     144                 :            : //   absl::string_view(nullptr, 0) == absl:: string_view("abcdef"+6, 0)
     145                 :            : class string_view {
     146                 :            :  public:
     147                 :            :   using traits_type = std::char_traits<char>;
     148                 :            :   using value_type = char;
     149                 :            :   using pointer = char*;
     150                 :            :   using const_pointer = const char*;
     151                 :            :   using reference = char&;
     152                 :            :   using const_reference = const char&;
     153                 :            :   using const_iterator = const char*;
     154                 :            :   using iterator = const_iterator;
     155                 :            :   using const_reverse_iterator = std::reverse_iterator<const_iterator>;
     156                 :            :   using reverse_iterator = const_reverse_iterator;
     157                 :            :   using size_type = size_t;
     158                 :            :   using difference_type = std::ptrdiff_t;
     159                 :            : 
     160                 :            :   static constexpr size_type npos = static_cast<size_type>(-1);
     161                 :            : 
     162                 :            :   // Null `string_view` constructor
     163                 :            :   constexpr string_view() noexcept : ptr_(nullptr), length_(0) {}
     164                 :            :

     166                 :            :

     170                 :            :           str) noexcept
     171                 :      31550 :       : ptr_(str.data()), length_(CheckLengthInternal(str.size())) {}
     172                 :            :

     199                 :            :   // access it results in undefined behavior.
     200                 :     175170 :   constexpr const_iterator end() const noexcept { return ptr_ + length_; }

     210                 :            :   // Returns a const iterator pointing just beyond the last character at the end

     212                 :            :   // access its element results in undefined behavior.
     213                 :            :   constexpr const_iterator cend() const noexcept { return end(); }

     286                 :            :   //
     287                 :            :   // Returns a pointer to the underlying character array (which is of course
     288                 :            :   // stored elsewhere). Note that `string_view::data()` may contain embedded nul
     289                 :            :   // characters, but the returned buffer may or may not be nul-terminated;
     290                 :            :   // therefore, do not pass `data()` to a routine that expects a nul-terminated
     291                 :            :   // std::string.
     292                 :       3286 :   constexpr const_pointer data() const noexcept { return ptr_; }
     293                 :            : 
     294                 :            :   // Modifiers

     296                 :            :   // string_view::remove_prefix()
     297                 :            :   //
     298                 :            :   // Removes the first `n` characters from the `string_view`. Note that the
     299                 :            :   // underlying std::string is not changed, only the view.
     300                 :            :   void remove_prefix(size_type n) {
     301                 :            :     assert(n <= length_);
     302                 :            :     ptr_ += n;
     303                 :            :     length_ -= n;
     304                 :            :   }
     305                 :            : 
     306                 :            :   // string_view::remove_suffix()
     307                 :            :   //
     308                 :            :   // Removes the last `n` characters from the `string_view`. Note that the
     309                 :            :   // underlying std::string is not changed, only the view.
     310                 :            :   void remove_suffix(size_type n) {
     311                 :            :     assert(n <= length_);

     313                 :            :   }
     314                 :            :

     319                 :            :     auto t = *this;

     339                 :            :   // string_view::substr()
     340                 :            :   //
     341                 :            :   // Returns a "substring" of the `string_view` (at offset `pos` and length
     342                 :            :   // `n`) as another string_view. This function throws `std::out_of_bounds` if
     343                 :            :   // `pos > size'.
     344                 :      29257 :   string_view substr(size_type pos, size_type n = npos) const {
     345         [ -  + ]:      29257 :     if (ABSL_PREDICT_FALSE(pos > length_))
     346                 :          0 :       base_internal::ThrowStdOutOfRange("absl::string_view::substr");
     347         [ +  - ]:      29257 :     n = std::min(n, length_ - pos);
     348                 :      29257 :     return string_view(ptr_ + pos, n);
     349                 :            :   }
     350                 :            : 
     351                 :            :   // string_view::compare()
     352                 :            :   //
     353                 :            :   // Performs a lexicographical comparison between the `string_view` and
     354                 :            :   // another `absl::string_view), returning -1 if `this` is less than, 0 if
     355                 :            :   // `this` is equal to, and 1 if `this` is greater than the passed std::string
     356                 :            :   // view. Note that in the case of data equality, a further comparison is made
     357                 :            :   // on the respective sizes of the two `string_view`s to determine which is
     358                 :            :   // smaller, equal, or greater.
     359                 :            :   int compare(string_view x) const noexcept {
     360                 :            :     auto min_length = std::min(length_, x.length_);
     361                 :            :     if (min_length > 0) {
     362                 :            :       int r = memcmp(ptr_, x.ptr_, min_length);
     363                 :            :       if (r < 0) return -1;
     364                 :            :       if (r > 0) return 1;
     365                 :            :     }
     366                 :            :     if (length_ < x.length_) return -1;
     367                 :            :     if (length_ > x.length_) return 1;
     368                 :            :     return 0;
     369                 :            :   }
     370                 :            : 
     371                 :            :   // Overload of `string_view::compare()` for comparing a substring of the
     372                 :            :   // 'string_view` and another `absl::string_view`.
     373                 :            :   int compare(size_type pos1, size_type count1, string_view v) const {
     374                 :            :     return substr(pos1, count1).compare(v);
     375                 :            :   }
     376                 :            :

     379                 :            :   int compare(size_type pos1, size_type count1, string_view v, size_type pos2,
     380                 :            :               size_type count2) const {
     381                 :            :     return substr(pos1, count1).compare(v.substr(pos2, count2));
     382                 :            :   }

     387                 :            :

     426                 :            :   // string_view::find_first_of()
     427                 :            :   //
     428                 :            :   // Finds the first occurrence of any of the characters in `s` within the
     429                 :            :   // `string_view`, returning the start position of the match, or `npos` if no
     430                 :            :   // match was found.
     431                 :            :   size_type find_first_of(string_view s, size_type pos = 0) const
     432                 :            :       noexcept;
     433                 :            : 
     434                 :            :   // Overload of `string_view::find_first_of()` for finding a character `c`
     435                 :            :   // within the `string_view`.
     436                 :            :   size_type find_first_of(char c, size_type pos = 0) const
     437                 :            :       noexcept {
     438                 :            :     return find(c, pos);
     439                 :            :   }

     446                 :            :   size_type find_last_of(string_view s, size_type pos = npos) const

     473                 :            :                                           size_type pos = npos) const noexcept;

     478                 :            :       noexcept;
     479                 :            : 
     480                 :            :  private:
     481                 :            :   static constexpr size_type kMaxSize =
     482                 :            :       std::numeric_limits<difference_type>::max();
     483                 :            : 
     484                 :            :   // check whether __builtin_strlen is provided by the compiler.
     485                 :            :   // GCC doesn't have __has_builtin()
     486                 :            :   // (https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=66970),
     487                 :            :   // but has __builtin_strlen according to
     488                 :            :   // https://gcc.gnu.org/onlinedocs/gcc-4.7.0/gcc/Other-Builtins.html.
     489                 :            : #if ABSL_HAVE_BUILTIN(__builtin_strlen) || \
     490                 :            :     (defined(__GNUC__) && !defined(__clang__))
     491                 :       1363 :   static constexpr size_type StrLenInternal(const char* str) {
     492         [ +  - ]:       1363 :     return str ? __builtin_strlen(str) : 0;
     493                 :            :   }
     494                 :            : #else
     495                 :            :   static constexpr size_type StrLenInternal(const char* str) {
     496                 :            :     return str ? strlen(str) : 0;
     497                 :            :   }
     498                 :            : #endif
     499                 :            : 
     500                 :       2334 :   static constexpr size_type CheckLengthInternal(size_type len) {
     501         [ -  + ]:       2334 :     return ABSL_ASSERT(len <= kMaxSize), len;
           [ -  +  #  # ]
     502                 :            :   }
     503                 :            : 
     504                 :            :   const char* ptr_;
     505                 :            :   size_type length_;
     506                 :            : };
     507                 :            : 
     508                 :            : // This large function is defined inline so that in a fairly common case where
     509                 :            : // one of the arguments is a literal, the compiler can elide a lot of the
     510                 :            : // following comparisons.
     511                 :            : inline bool operator==(string_view x, string_view y) noexcept {
     512                 :            :   auto len = x.size();
     513                 :            :   if (len != y.size()) {
     514                 :            :     return false;
     515                 :            :   }
     516                 :            :   return x.data() == y.data() || len <= 0 ||
     517                 :            :          memcmp(x.data(), y.data(), len) == 0;
     518                 :            : }
     519                 :            : 
     520                 :            : inline bool operator!=(string_view x, string_view y) noexcept {
     521                 :            :   return !(x == y);
     522                 :            : }
     523                 :            : 
     524                 :            : inline bool operator<(string_view x, string_view y) noexcept {
     525                 :            :   auto min_size = std::min(x.size(), y.size());
     526                 :            :   const int r = min_size == 0 ? 0 : memcmp(x.data(), y.data(), min_size);
     527                 :            :   return (r < 0) || (r == 0 && x.size() < y.size());
     528                 :            : }
     529                 :            : 
     530                 :            : inline bool operator>(string_view x, string_view y) noexcept { return y < x; }
     531                 :            : 
     532                 :            : inline bool operator<=(string_view x, string_view y) noexcept {
     533                 :            :   return !(y < x);
     534                 :            : }
     535                 :            : 
     536                 :            : inline bool operator>=(string_view x, string_view y) noexcept {
     537                 :            :   return !(x < y);
     538                 :            : }
     539                 :            : 
     540                 :            : // IO Insertion Operator
     541                 :            : std::ostream& operator<<(std::ostream& o, string_view piece);
     542                 :            : 
     543                 :            : }  // namespace absl
     544                 :            : 
     545                 :            : #endif  // ABSL_HAVE_STD_STRING_VIEW
     546                 :            : 
     547                 :            : namespace absl {
     548                 :            : 
     549                 :            : // ClippedSubstr()
     550                 :            : //
     551                 :            : // Like `s.substr(pos, n)`, but clips `pos` to an upper bound of `s.size()`.
     552                 :            : // Provided because std::string_view::substr throws if `pos > size()`
     553                 :            : inline string_view ClippedSubstr(string_view s, size_t pos,
     554                 :            :                                  size_t n = string_view::npos) {
     555                 :            :   pos = std::min(pos, static_cast<size_t>(s.size()));
     556                 :            :   return s.substr(pos, n);
     557                 :            : }
     558                 :            : 
     559                 :            : // NullSafeStringView()
     560                 :            : //
     561                 :            : // Creates an `absl::string_view` from a pointer `p` even if it's null-valued.
     562                 :            : // This function should be used where an `absl::string_view` can be created from
     563                 :            : // a possibly-null pointer.
     564                 :            : inline string_view NullSafeStringView(const char* p) {
     565                 :            :   return p ? string_view(p) : string_view();
     566                 :            : }
     567                 :            : 
     568                 :            : }  // namespace absl
     569                 :            : 
     570                 :            : #endif  // ABSL_STRINGS_STRING_VIEW_H_
